Introduction.content:
Golden, puffed-up, melt-in-your-mouth **Puri** (also called Poori or Chapati za Mviringo) â€“ the king of festive breakfasts and street snacks from India to East Africa, the Middle East, and the Caribbean.

When done right, they puff into perfect balloons, stay soft inside, and disappear in seconds. This is the exact recipe used by the best puri sellers in Dar es Salaam, Stone Town, Mumbai, Nairobi, and London.

Perfect for breakfast with chai, mahamri & mbaazi, potato curry, or selling on the street. Works anywhere in the world!

Chapter 1: Ingredients (Makes 20â€“25 me.content:
- 500 g (4 cups) all-purpose flour or atta flour (white wheat flour)
- 1 tsp salt
- 1 tsp sugar (helps puffing and golden colour)
- 2 tbsp oil or ghee (for soft dough)
- 180â€“200 ml water (lukewarm)
- Extra flour for rolling
- Oil for deep frying (enough to fully submerge puri)

Optional for extra softness:
- 2 tbsp semolina (sooji) OR 2 tbsp plain yogurt OR Â¼ cup milk

Chapter 2: Step 1 â€“ Make the Perfect D.content:
1. Mix flour + salt + sugar in a large bowl
2. Add oil/ghee â†’ rub with fingers until flour feels like breadcrumbs
3. Add water little by little â†’ knead 8â€“10 minutes until you get a **firm but smooth dough** (stiffer than chapati dough)
4. The dough should be **slightly hard** â€“ this is the #1 secret to perfect puffing!
5. Smear 1 tsp oil on top â†’ cover with damp cloth â†’ rest 20â€“30 minutes

Pro tip: If you press the dough with a finger and it springs back slowly, itâ€™s perfect.

Chapter 3: Step 2 â€“ Roll Even Circles.content:
1. Divide dough into 20â€“25 equal balls (size of a small lime)
2. Dip each ball lightly in dry flour
3. Roll into perfect circles 10â€“12 cm (4â€“5 inches) â€“ **not too thin, not too thick** (about 2 mm)
4. Keep rolled puri covered with cloth so they donâ€™t dry out

Secret: Roll all puri first before frying â€“ they puff better when freshly rolled.

Chapter 4: Step 3 â€“ Fry to Perfect Bal.content:
### The Magic Puffing Technique
1. Heat oil in a deep kadai/wok on **medium-high** (180â€“190Â°C)
2. Test: drop a tiny piece of dough â€“ it should rise immediately with bubbles
3. Gently slide one puri into hot oil
4. After 3â€“4 seconds, **press very lightly** with a slotted spoon (this forces steam inside)
5. It will puff into a beautiful balloon!
6. Flip once â†’ fry other side 10â€“15 seconds until golden
7. Remove â†’ drain on paper towel

Every single puri MUST puff â€“ if not, your oil is not hot enough or dough is too soft.

Chapter 5: Troubleshooting â€“ Why It Di.content:
- Didnâ€™t puff at all â†’ dough too soft or wet / oil not hot enough
- Puffed then collapsed â†’ dough too thin or had cracks
- Hard and crispy â†’ too much frying time or dough too dry
- Dark brown â†’ oil too hot
- Oily puri â†’ oil not hot enough

Fix: Knead slightly harder dough next time + perfect oil temperature = 100% puff success!

Chapter 6: Variations Around the World.content:
- **Spicy Puri** â†’ add 1 tsp chili powder + cumin to dough
- **Sweet Puri** â†’ increase sugar to 3â€“4 tbsp
- **Palak Puri** â†’ blend spinach with water and use green dough
- **Bedouin-style** â†’ larger size, served with honey
- **East African style** â†’ smaller size, served with mbaazi or ndengu curry

Chapter 7: Storage & Reheating.content:
- Best eaten fresh and hot!
- Keep warm in covered pot up to 2 hours
- Reheat: microwave 10 seconds OR lightly fry again 5 seconds per side
- Freeze cooked puri â†’ re-fry from frozen for 20â€“30 seconds
